articles.headline: Four Wheels for the Masses: The $2,500 Car
articles.snippet: A new car from Tata Motors of India would likely fail Western emission and safety standards, but it could be an affordable car for the developing world.
articles.abstract: A new car from Tata Motors of India would likely fail Western emission and safety standards, but it could be an affordable car for the developing world.
articles.lead_paragraph: MUMBAI, India  What does it take to build the world’s cheapest car?

articles.headline: Bush Admits Economy Faces Challenges
articles.snippet: Both the president and Congressional Democratic leaders are considering a rescue package to counter the threat of a recession.
articles.abstract: Both the president and Congressional Democratic leaders are considering a rescue package to counter the threat of a recession.
articles.lead_paragraph: CHICAGO  President Bush, in a marked shift from his usual upbeat economic assessments, conceded here on Monday that the nation faces “economic challenges” due to rising oil prices, the home mortgage crisis and a weakening job market.
articles.byline: By Sheryl Gay Stolberg and David M. Herszenhorn

articles.headline: Two Hopefuls Share Little but Youth Appeal
articles.snippet: A tidal wave of young voters is buoying the disparate campaigns of both Senators Barack Obama and John McCain.
articles.abstract: A tidal wave of young voters is buoying the disparate campaigns of both Senators Barack Obama and John McCain.
articles.lead_paragraph: MANCHESTER, N.H.  It has the feel and look of a transformative moment, this tidal wave of young voters buoying the disparate campaigns of Senators Barack Obama and John McCain.

articles.headline: Justices Chilly to Bid to Alter Death Penalty
articles.snippet: An effort to change the way states carry out executions by lethal injection appeared to founder before the Supreme Court.
articles.abstract: An effort to change the way states carry out executions by lethal injection appeared to founder before the Supreme Court.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  With conservative justices questioning their motives and liberal justices questioning their evidence, opponents of the American manner of capital punishment made little headway Monday in their effort to persuade the Supreme Court that the Constitution requires states to change the way they carry out executions by lethal injection.

articles.headline: Strikebound, the Globes Scale Back Awards
articles.snippet: The festive awards dinner will be replaced on Sunday night by a news conference to announce the prize winners.
articles.abstract: The festive awards dinner will be replaced on Sunday night by a news conference to announce the prize winners.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES  Are the Golden Globes, the annual movie and television awards given out by the Hollywood Foreign Press Association, really news?
articles.byline: By Michael Cieply and David Carr

articles.headline: Obama’s Surge Deflates Forum and Talk of a Bloomberg Run
articles.snippet: The momentum of Barack Obama’s campaign seemed to steal energy from an event that had the potential to be a big moment for Michael Bloomberg’s potential presidential bid.
articles.abstract: The momentum of Barack Obama’s campaign seemed to steal energy from an event that had the potential to be a big moment for Michael Bloomberg’s potential presidential bid.
articles.lead_paragraph: NORMAN, Okla.  He arrived here for what seemed like it could be a big moment. Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg, eyeing a third-party presidential bid, joined Republican and Democratic elders at a forum to denounce the extreme partisanship of Washington and plot how to influence the campaign.
articles.byline: By Raymond Hernandez and Nicholas Confessore

articles.headline: A Safety-Net Hospital Falls Into Financial Crisis
articles.snippet: The struggles of a venerable Atlanta charity hospital mirror those of other public hospitals across the nation.
articles.abstract: The struggles of a venerable Atlanta charity hospital mirror those of other public hospitals across the nation.
articles.lead_paragraph: ATLANTA  Pamela Vaughn is a Grady baby.
articles.byline: By Shaila Dewan and Kevin Sack

articles.headline: Questioning an Adviser’s Advice
articles.snippet: If you’re a chief executive under siege, Martin Lipton is the lawyer to call.
articles.abstract: If you’re a chief executive under siege, Martin Lipton is the lawyer to call.
articles.lead_paragraph: “Come on, you can say it. I’m a professional entrencher of management.”

articles.headline: The Debate Over How and How Long
articles.snippet: President Bush is likely to respond to recession fears much as he did on entering office in 2001, but this time around Democrats are planning to push back.
articles.abstract: President Bush is likely to respond to recession fears much as he did on entering office in 2001, but this time around Democrats are planning to push back.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  If President Bush becomes convinced the economy is indeed headed toward a recession, he is likely to respond much as he did on entering office in 2001 with the economy on the verge of a downturn: lower tax rates for people at all income levels and provide tax breaks for businesses.

articles.headline: Bear’s Cayne to Quit as Chief Executive
articles.snippet: James E. Cayne, the embattled chief executive of Bear Stearns, will step down after the deepest losses in the firm’s history, according to people who have been briefed on the situation.
articles.abstract: James E. Cayne, the embattled chief executive of Bear Stearns, will step down after the deepest losses in the firm’s history, according to people who have been briefed on the situation.
articles.lead_paragraph: James E. Cayne, the embattled chief executive of Bear Stearns, will step down after the deepest losses in the firm’s history, according to people who have been briefed on the situation.

articles.headline: On Eve of Primary, Clinton Campaign Shows Stress
articles.snippet: If Hillary Rodham Clinton loses in New Hampshire, everything will be on the table, her advisers say.
articles.abstract: If Hillary Rodham Clinton loses in New Hampshire, everything will be on the table, her advisers say.
articles.lead_paragraph: PORTSMOUTH, N.H.  Key campaign officials may be replaced. She may start calling herself the underdog. Donors would receive pleas that it is do-or-die time. And her political strategy could begin mirroring that of Rudolph W. Giuliani, a Republican rival, by focusing on populous states like California and New York whose primaries are Feb. 5.
